newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia housing outlook seen strong near-term.
newsitem.headline: Australia housing outlook seen strong near-term.

text.p: The recovery in the Australian building industry would continue for another two years before easing back over the longer term, forecasting group BIS Shrapnel Pty Ltd said in a report on Monday.
BIS forecast a 10 percent rise in building commencements in 1997/98 (July-June) and a 0.4 percent increase in 1998/99 after seven percent growth in 1996/97.

The report, which considers building trends to 2012, forecast that average annual total building starts over the five years to 2001/02 would be six per cent higher than the average for the five years to 1997.
Non-residential building and construction starts were forecast to rise 11 percent in 1997/98, taking activity to its highest level for almost 10 years.
However, BIS expected to the market to fall 10 percent in 1998/99 through a A$500 million decline in entertainment and recreational building projects.
Over the next five years, the report said the average annual level of new residential activity would remain stable, before declining six percent over the five years to 2007.
Residential alterations and additions would be the buoyant sector over the next 15 years with annual compound growth of 2.4 percent, it said.
